What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.

Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: integral calc, series, basic diff eq, etc.
I went from knowing almost nothing about calculus to knowing more than I ever thought I would.
I learned how to learn math at a college level, as that wasn't something I really had experience with before, and it's so different.
Great knowledge of how to take integrals and determine convergence/divergence of series/power series. Mediocre understanding of the FTC and the underlying formulas behind riemann sums.
I developed a greater understanding of Calculus concepts.
You'll learn more techniques for taking integrals, how to work with  sequences and series, and how to solve differential equations.
I learned how to deal with complex problems involving series and Taylor series, and learned how to apply them to integral equations and graphs
How to work with integrals, series, parametric and polar functions, differential equations.
apply materials we learn in class
Learned how to think about math and how to approach problems involving many skills learned throughout the course.
I developed my integration skills and expanded my knowledge of calculus. This class really pushed me to not just memorize equations  but understand the fundamentals.
Learned some new math topics that were not covered in my high school math class.
calculus
Strengths: Lam's section makes you learn math and not just memorize algorithms for how to solve basic types of problems

Strengths: Teaches a lot of useful/interesting concepts in math.

Weaknesses: Poorly structured, the whole backwards classroom system is bad. It is even worse when your instructor does not make an effort to sync up with the content being taught in the videos.

Strengths on the conceptual side of series and the problem solving side of integrals. Weaknesses on the conceptual side of integrals and probelm solving side of series. The single biggest weakness was the flipped classroom. I am yet to meet someone who liked the flipped classroom, it sucks!
I think the strengths are the teaching of the concepts, but the weaknesses are that it is difficult to learn in the environment that I was taught in.

Strengths: the preclass videos were very good for explaining the concepts so that the majority of classes could be spent doing practice problems. 

Weaknesses: Unless you really like math, this class was difficult to stay engaged in.

Strengths:
-preclass videos
Weaknesses: 
-pace was fast
This course needs much better and clearer teaching styles.

There is a lot of discrepancies between the material learned in video lectures, class textbook, as well as between sections themselves. The course was somewhat disjointed, which made the material harder than it needed to be. It was hard to gauge what was expected of us due to these discrepancies.
I did not like the fact that it was a flipped classroom. The textbook is very well written though.
Weakness: moved at a pace too fast

pro- smallish sections so you can ask questions 

con- if you have a bad teacher, it will be hard to learn

If you are considering a math-related field you are probably shopping this class because you have to. Don't be too put off by the reviews - it's really an okay class. If you are good at math and put in a medium amount of work you will do fine, and some of the Taylor series material is pretty interesting.
Take it if you must. It's not really a good course but most people have no choice. Avoid taking it with Lam Pham if possible.
Yes.
If you have to progress in Math then obviously. If not, I would avoid MATH 115.
I would recommend it to someone who needs to fulfill a course requirement. Other than that, I would not recommend this to another student.
Only if you need it as a pre-req for something else.
Yes
Yes but only to fulfill a prereq
no
Would recommend for the material (there are no substitute courses), but the course itself could do with some improvement
I only would recommend this course to a student who is very passionate about math and who did well in math in high school.
yes if its a pre requisite for something
